p: Furthermore, based on the results of the survey conducted in Athens, citizens are willing to pay a considerable premium for effective protection against the spread of unfamiliar diseases, thus implying a risk-averting behavior against invasive mosquito threats. In other words, citizens are willing to pay today for improved control programs that will be able to eliminate potential future impacts and risks. The fact that climate change trends may worsen the mosquito problem and increase the risks of the transmission of new diseases (such as Zika virus) is likely to provide ever increasing potential individual and social benefits from implementing more efficient mosquito control management plans in the coming years [ 40].
